The Cestus, which the graces wove,</br>And laughing Venus wore,</br>Where centered all the power of love,</br>By which all lovers swore.
Has been to various charms compared,</br>In various figures drest;</br>And thus the sentimental bard</br>His tender creed confess'd:
'Tis Sympathy's resistless tears,</br>Which melt the stubborn heart;</br>Awake a thousand anxious fears,</br>A thousand joys impart.
Such childish transports I despise,</br>(Exclaim'd a sprightlier swain,)</br>And Wit must revel in those eyes</br>Which give my bosom pain.
Hold, (said the philosophic sage)</br>'Tis Wisdom I aver,</br>Which charms mankind in every age;</br>I pay my vows to her.
Thus vainly have they oft explored</br>The mental catalogue;</br>And ev'ry beauty been adored,</br>And ev'ry grace in vogue.
Unweeting bards!  who thus insult</br>Their godships' finer taste;</br>And think that they, on charms occult,</br>Etherial sighs would waste.
For, if their breasts (as poets tell)</br>With mortal passions glow,</br>Not even Beauty's potent spell</br>Could deal the fatal blow.
The little tyrant of the skies</br>Had pass'd unheeded by,</br>Nor the soft lustre of her eyes</br>Been honor'd with a sigh.
Then, if aright I ween, this zone</br>(Which woke the plaintive verse,</br>And triumph'd o'er the heart of stone,)</br>Was but a simple purse.
Nay, do not rave, ye whimpering swains,</br>And talk of love sincere;</br>For all your extacies and pains</br>Concentre only here.
Could you but learn the happy art,</br>By Midas known of old;</br>You'd e'en transform the fair one's heart</br>And ev'ry nerve to gold.</br>
